title: Tory cuts have removed one of the escape routes for women facing domestic violence
text:
News Opinion Tory cuts have removed one of the escape routes for women facing domestic violence While the Chancellor was continuing policies that have closed women's refuges, a moving patchwork quilt with the names of 598 murdered women was unveiled outside Parliament Share The patches on this memorial can't repair the damage created by cuts (Photo: Tim Anderson) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
The names are stitched neatly in bright colours by volunteers, each one inside a square of patchwork quilt. Tracy Jones, Victoria Rose, Hannah Windsor, Mariam Mahdaqi, Rachael Slack, ­Madina Landsberg. 598 names in total. 
What looks like a handmade bedspread is actually a deeply affecting memorial. Each hand-stitched square represents a woman killed by their partner or ex-partner – a permanent record of the names of all the women killed in England and Wales between 2009 and 2015. Two women a week. 
On Wednesday, these neat squares representing unimaginable loss and violence came to the heart of Parliament because it was International Women’s Day (IWD). But the timing was more poignant even than that – as Labour MPs and Lords ­gathered at the quilt on their way to watch a Budget on which human lives depend. 
The inexcusable truth is that Government cuts have directly led to the number of squares needing to be stitched more quickly. As a recent placard on a Sisters Uncut protest about refuge closures in Portsmouth said: “Cutting domestic violence services is violence against women.” 
Since 2010, austerity’s axe has inflicted pain on local ­councils, which in turn have been forced to make more dangerous cuts. Refuges have been one of the worst hit services, despite providing life-saving help for women escaping domestic violence. 
More than 30 refuges have been cut since 2010. The charity Refuge, the biggest provider of services, has seen cuts of over 80%. Women’s Aid says 17% of specialist women’s refuges have closed since 2010, with more than 155 women a day turned away because of a lack of space. Read More What the 2017 Budget means for you - the key points that will make you richer or poorer More than 30 women's refuges have been cut since 2010, despite providing life-saving help for abused women (Photo: Getty) 
On Wednesday, a Budget from an overly confident Chancellor ­apparently delivered £20million to tackle domestic violence. That money is a massive victory for campaigners, but it was money already promised and not nearly enough to replace the millions cut from domestic violence services and refuges by seven years of austerity. 
There is deep hypocrisy in decimating council budgets that used to fund refuges in a stable, long-term way that allowed services to plan for the future, while announcing International Women’s Day largesse through Mumsnet – just as Theresa May hosted an IWD event at Downing Street. 
In the hard, cold, real world, ­councils are being cut back to ­statutory services only – and refuges are, incredibly, not a statutory service. No council is obliged to fund one. 
Sisters Uncut hears a disturbing echo here. “When perpetrators abuse survivors, they often hold them in spaces of economic uncertainty, making them constantly unsure about income and unable to plan for the future or control their own lives, forcing them to focus on surviving not thriving,” they say. “The Government’s treatment of the domestic violence sector mirrors this.” 
In that context, the Women’s Quilt, 598 hand-stitched squares standing firm in the wind and rain outside Parliament, spoke up powerfully for women no longer able to speak for themselves. 
Roxanne Ellis, a Labour councillor from Nottingham, had the idea of creating it after reading the Nia and Women’s Aid Femicide Census which, for the first time, reported the names and profiles of the hundreds of women murdered every year in incidents of domestic violence. Read More Domestic violence victim reveals shocking footage of drunken boyfriend crippling her in horrific attack This week's Budget announcement took with two hands and gave with one (Photo: Getty) 
“I thought that the women killed should be remembered for who they were and what they did, not just as a statistic,” Roxanne says. 
Dozens of volunteers recruited through Facebook chose a woman to commemorate because they knew them, or because they lived near them or shared a name. Many also shared experiences of domestic violence or coercive control. 
“Many volunteers researched the women and their stories are heartbreaking,” says Roxanne, who adds that at one time she was in an emotionally abusive relationship herself. 
“They come from every community and every corner of England and Wales. The only thing they have in common is that they were killed by someone they loved and who they thought loved them.” 
Frances Bill, 66, from Brighton, says she became involved through Facebook. She travelled to Parliament to see the finished quilt after stitching two squares, for Naila Mumtaz and Frances Cleary-Senior. 
“I picked Frances because she had the same name as me,” she says. 
To get some personal detail into the patches she looked up the cases. 
Naila Mumtaz was 21 when she was killed by her husband and three other male family members. She was also six months pregnant. 
“I found what I read so distressing,” Frances said. “Frances and I had the same name, and were similar ages. She was 49. She was an ophthalmic nurse, stabbed through the heart. I stitched some beads that look like eyes onto her patch. Her sister got in touch to say how touched she was.” 
Behind her, inside the chamber of the House of Commons, the Chancellor was taking away from women suffering domestic violence with two hands and giving with one, with ever-deeper cuts stitched into the fabric of his Budget. Like us on Facebook
